                                                      Quantum Basics

                                                      Hilbert space : H=C2n

                                                      wave function : |ϕ⟩∈H

                                                      • a spin-12 system, H=C2, ϕ=α|↑⟩+β|↓⟩|α|2+|β|2=1

                                                      • basic state : |↑⟩=[10]|↓⟩=[01]|→⟩=12[11]

                                                      pauli matrices : σx=[0110] σy=[0−ii0] σz=[100−1]

                                                      • σi=σi† : Hermitian

                                                      • σi=σi−1 : involutory

                                                      • σi2=I

                                                      • |σi|=−1 : determinant

                                                      • Tr(σi)=0 : trace

                                                      • λ=±1 : eigen values, eigen vectors are positive negative axes in Bloch sphere

                                                      • [σi,σj]=2iϵijkσk : commutation, ϵijk : Levi-Civita symbol

                                                      • {σi,σj}=2δijI : anti-commutation, δij : kronecker delta

                                                      Operators :

                                                      • spin operator : S^x=ℏ2σxS^y=ℏ2σyS^z=ℏ2σz

                                                        • spin pointing along direction e→=[ex,ey,ez] e→⋅S→^=ℏ2[ezex−ieyex+iey−ez]

                                                      • position operator : q^|ψ(q)⟩=qψ(q)

                                                      • momentum operator : p^=−iℏddq

                                                      • hamiltonian operator : H^=−ℏ22m∇2+V

                                                      • kinetic operator : T^=(p→)^22m=−iℏ22m∇2

                                                      • potential operator : V^=V

                                                      Schrödinger equation ：iℏ∂t|ψ(t)⟩=H^|ψ(t)⟩

                                                      • for stationary problem : H^|ψ⟩=E|ψ⟩ψ(t)=e−iEt/ℏ|ψ(0)⟩

                                                      • external potential : iℏ∂tψ(r^)=−ℏ22m∇2ψ(r→)+V(r→)ψ(r→)

                                                      Notation

                                                      • H^ Hamilton operator

                                                      • E energy of the system

                                                      • V potential

                                                      Example

                                                      • harmonic oscillator : 12(p^2+q^2)|ψ⟩=E|ψ⟩

                                                        • V(q^)=12q^2

                                                        • ψ(q)=12nn!ℏπe−q2/2Hn(1ℏq)

                                                        • E=ℏ(n+12)

                                                      Density matrix : ρ^=∑i,jpi,j|ψi⟩⟨ψj|

                                                      • purity of the system Tr(ρ^2)

                                                      • for a pure state without noise : ρ^pure=|ψ⟩⟨ψ|

                                                        Example

                                                        ρ^→=|→⟩⟨→|=[12121212]

                                                        Tr(ρ^→)=1

                                                        ρ^↑↓=|↑⟩⟨↓|=[120012]

                                                        Tr(ρ^↑↓)=12

                                                      • unitary time evolution : iℏ∂tρ^(t)=[H^,ρ^(t)]

                                                      • thermal density matrix : ρ^β=1∑ie−βEi∑ie−βEi|i⟩⟨i|=1Tr(e−βH^)e−βH^

                                                         

                                                      measurement : ⟨ψ|A^|ψ⟩=Tr(ρ^A^)

                                                      • measure non commute operator : [A^,B^]=iℏ⇔ΔA⋅ΔB≥ℏ2

                                                         

                                                       

                                                      Quantum 1-body problem

                                                      given V ,we want to know ψ according to Schrödinger equation −ℏ22m∂x2ψ(x)+V(x)ψ(x)=Eψ(x)

                                                      Time-Independent 1 D Schrödinger equation

                                                      stationary assumption : ψ(t)=e−iEt/ℏ|ψ(0)⟩

                                                      −ℏ22m∇2ψ(x)+V(x)ψ(x)=Eψ(x)→Hψ(x)=Eψ(x)

                                                      for special form

                                                      ψ″(x)+2mℏ2(E−V(x))ψ(x)=0

                                                      given V,m,E we want to know ψ

                                                      Numerov algorithm

                                                      (1+(Δx)212kn+1)ψn+1=2(1−5(Δx)212kn)ψn−(1+(Δx)212kn−1)ψn−1+O[(Δx)6]k=2mℏ2(E−V(x))

                                                      • initial problem for symmetry V(x)=V(−x)

                                                        • ψ(x)=−ψ(x) : half integer mesh with ψ(−12Δx)=ψ(12Δx)=1

                                                        • ψ(−x)=−ψ(x) : integer mesh with ψ(0)=0ψ(Δx)=1

                                                      • general V(x)=0 for |x|≥a

                                                        • ψ(−a−Δx)=exp(−Δx−2mE/ℏ)ψ(−a)=1

                                                      1D scattering problem

                                                      a particle approaching the potential barrier V(x){≠0x∈[0,a]=0others from the left

                                                      • wave function assumptions :

                                                        • left (x<0) wave function : ψL(x)=Aeiqx⏟origin wave+Be−iqx⏟reflection

                                                        • right (x>a) wave function : ψR(x)=Ceiqx⏟transmission

                                                        • where q is the wave number q2=2m[E−V(x)]ℏ2

                                                      • solution :

                                                        Algorithm

                                                        1. set C=1, use Numerov algorithm starting at a+Δx from right to left

                                                        2. match the numerical solution on the left x<0 to determine A and B

                                                      • probability :

                                                        • reflection probaility : R=|B|2|A|2

                                                        • transition probability : T=|C|2|A|2

                                                      Bound state

                                                      particles are confined due to potential V(x){<0x∈[0,a]=0others

                                                      • shooting method for eigen solver

                                                        Algorithm

                                                        1. try a energy E

                                                        2. use numerov algorithm from x=0 to xf≫a

                                                        3. satisfy ψE(xf)≈0 then E is a eigenvalue else try another E

                                                      • Improved Method - Integration from Both Sides

                                                        Algorithm

                                                        1. try a position b∈(0,a) , that E=V(b), ∂2ψE∂x2=0

                                                        2. use numerov from to b as ψL and from 0 to b as ψR

                                                        3. satisfy ψL′(b)ψL(b)=ψR′(b)ψR(b) (ψL,ψR are not normalized ), then E is a eigenvalue else try another b

                                                       

                                                      Time-independent nD Schrödinger equation

                                                      Factorization techniques :

                                                      • along coordinate axes : ψ(r→)=ψx(x)ψy(y)ψz(z)

                                                      • spherical symmetry : ψ(r→)=u(r)rYlm(θ,ϕ)l∈N0,m∈Z,|m|≤l

                                                        apply to the Schrodinger equation : (−ℏ22μ∇2+ℏ2l(l+1)2μr2+V(r))u(r)=Eu(r)

                                                        Notation

                                                        • l : azimuthal quantum number, magnitude of the orbital angular momentum

                                                        • m : magnetic quantum number, projection of the angular momentum vector along a chosen axis

                                                        • μ : mass

                                                      Solving methods :

                                                      • finite difference

                                                        Example : three dimensional Schrodinger

                                                        ∇2ψ(r→)+2m[E−V(r→)]ψ(r→)=0⇓0=1(Δx)2[ψ(xn+1,yn,zn)+ψ(xn−1,yn,zn)+ψ(xn,yn+1,zn)+ψ(xn,yn−1,zn)+ψ(xn,yn,zn+1)+ψ(xn,yn,zn−1)]+{2m[E−V(r→)]−6(Δx)2}ψ(xn,yn,zn)

                                                      • variational approaches : |ϕ⟩=∑iNai|ui⟩

                                                        ⟨ϕ|ϕ⟩E∗=⟨ϕ|H^|ϕ⟩→⟨ui|uj⟩⏟SijE∗=⟨ui|H^|uj⟩⏟Hij→U⊤HUb^=E∗b→

                                                        more basis more accurate

                                                        Notation

                                                        • |ui⟩ basis

                                                        • ai : basis coefficient, a→=[a1,⋯,an]⊤

                                                        • U : nomalization matrix for S that U⊤SU=I

                                                        • b→ : eigen vector, b→=U−1a→

                                                      • finite element method

                                                        • irregular geometries

                                                        • higher accuracy

                                                       

                                                      Time dependent Schrödinger Equation

                                                      i∂t|ψ⟩=H^|ψ⟩

                                                      Spectral method ：|ψt⟩=∑ncne−iεn(t−t0)/ℏ|ϕn⟩

                                                      Algorithm

                                                      1. eigen value εn and eigen vector |ϕn⟩ for stationary problem H^|ϕ⟩=E|ϕ⟩

                                                      2. represent initial wave function in eigen vectors |ψ0⟩=∑ncn|ϕn⟩

                                                      3. the evolution state |ψt⟩=∑ncne−iεn(t−t0)/ℏ|ϕn⟩

                                                      limitations :

                                                      • the diagonalization of is complex, so this method is only useful for small problems

                                                      Notation

                                                      • |ϕn⟩ : eigenvector of H|ϕ⟩=E|ϕ⟩, |ψ0⟩=∑cn|ϕn⟩

                                                      • εn : eigenvalue of H|ϕ⟩=E|ϕ⟩

                                                      Direct numerical integration : (1+iΔt2ℏH)ψ(r→,t+Δt)=(1−iΔt2ℏH)ψ(r→,t)

                                                      • forward euler : |ψ(tn+1)⟩=|ψ(tn)⟩−iΔtℏH^|ψ(tn)⟩

                                                        • numerically unstable

                                                        • violet conservation of ⟨ϕ|ϕ⟩

                                                      • implicit method : (1+iΔt2ℏH)ψ(r→,t+Δt)=(1−iΔt2ℏH)ψ(r→,t)

                                                        • is sparse matrix, using iterative solver (e.g. biconjugate gradient)

                                                      Split-operator method : ψ(q→)⇌F−1Fψ(p→)⇒H^=T^(p→)+V^(q→)

                                                      e−itH^/ℏ=e−iΔtV^/2ℏ[e−iΔtT^/ℏe−iΔtV^/ℏ]N−1e−iΔtT^/ℏe−iΔtV^/2ℏ

                                                      Algorithm

                                                      1. ψ(q→)←e−iΔtV(q→)/2ℏψ0(q→)

                                                      2. loop N-1 timesteps

                                                        1. ψ(p→)←Fψ(q→)

                                                        2. ψ(p→)←e−iΔtℏ‖p→‖2/2mψ(p→)

                                                        3. ψ(q→)←F−1ψ(p→)

                                                        4. ψ(q→)←e−iΔtV(q→)/ℏψ(q→)

                                                      3. ψ(p→)←Fψ(q→)

                                                      4. ψ(p→)←e−iΔtℏ‖p→‖2/2mψ(p→)

                                                      5. ψ(q→)←F−1ψ(p→)

                                                      6. ψ(q→)←e−iΔtV(q→)/2ℏ

                                                      Notation

                                                      • p→ : momentum in hamilton expression

                                                      • q→ : position in hamilton expression

                                                      • T^ : kinetic operator , T^=(p→)^22m=−iℏ22m∇2

                                                      • V^ : potential operator , V^=V

                                                      • F : fourier operator , Fψ(q→)=(12π)d∫−∞+∞ψ(q→)e−ip→⋅q→dq→

                                                      • F−1 : inverse fourier operator , F−1ψ(p→)=(12π)d∫−∞+∞ψ(p→)e−ip→⋅q→dp→

                                                       

                                                      Quantum n-body problem

                                                      Hilbert space for n particles: HN=H⊗N

                                                      Indistinguishable Particles

                                                      Bosons and Fermions :

                                                      • fermions : ψ(r→1,r→2)=−ψ(r→2,r→1)

                                                        ΨA=NA∑psign(p)ψ(r→p(1),⋯,r→p(N))

                                                        Notation

                                                        • ΨA : n particle fermions wave function

                                                        • NA : normalization factor

                                                        • p : permutation

                                                        • Pauli exclusion principle : ΨA(r→1,r→2)=ψ(r→1,r→2)−ψ(r→2,r→1)≠0

                                                        • spinful, generalized coordinate r=(r→,σ)

                                                      • bosons : ψ(r→1,r→2)=ψ(r→2,r→1)

                                                        ΨS=NS∑pψ(r→p(1),⋯,r→p(N))

                                                        Notation

                                                        • ΨS : n particle bosons wave function

                                                        • NS : normalization factor

                                                      Fock space: F=⨁N=0∞S±HN

                                                      possible particle configurations for a given type of particle

                                                      • F=F0⏟0 particles⊕F1⏟1 particles⊕⋯

                                                      Notation

                                                      • ⊕ : direct sum, e.g. A⊕B=[A00B]

                                                      • S± : symmetrization for bosons S+=NS∑p / antisymmetrization operator for fermions S−=NA∑psgn(p)

                                                      Example

                                                      Slater determinant :Ψ(r1,⋯,rN)=1N!|ϕ1(r1)⋯ϕN(r1)⋮⋱⋮ϕr(rN)⋯ϕN(rN)|

                                                      anti-symmetrized and normalized N single particle wave function product

                                                      Notation

                                                      • ϕi(rj) : wave function of fermion i at position rj

                                                      Creation and annihilation operators

                                                      • a^ annihilation operator : remove particle

                                                      • a^† creation operator : add particle

                                                      Notation

                                                      • |0⟩ : vacuum state with no particles, |0⟩=[00]

                                                      • [⋅,⋅] : commute, [A,B]=AB−BA

                                                      • {⋅,⋅} : anti-commute, {A,B}=AB+BA

                                                      • Bosons : commute

                                                        • a^i|ni⟩=ni|ni−1⟩a^i†|ni⟩=ni+1|ni+1⟩

                                                        • a^i†a^i=ni

                                                        • [a^i,a^j†]=δij[a^i,a^j]=[a^i†,a^j†]=0

                                                         

                                                      • Fermions : anti-commute

                                                          • ni=0 : c^i†c^i|uj,⋯⟩=0

                                                          • ni=1 :

                                                        • {c^i,c^j†}=δij{c^i,c^j}={c^i†,c^j†}=0

                                                        • 0↚c^ui†|0⟩⇌c^uic^ui†|ui⟩↛c^ui†0

                                                           

                                                       

                                                      Quantum Spin Model

                                                      (TFIM)Transverse field Ising model

                                                      H^=∑<ij>JijS^izS^jz−∑ihi2S^ix
                                                      S^izS^jz=I⊗⋯⊗S^z⏟n=i⊗⋯⊗S^z⏟n=j⊗⋯⊗1I

                                                      • quantum phase transition between a spontaneously symmetry-broken and a disordered phase

                                                      • extension of the classical Ising model by adding a magnetic field in the x direction

                                                      Notation

                                                      • <ij> : connection between particle i and particle j

                                                      • Jij : interacting constant between particle i and particle j

                                                      • hi : external magenatic field on particle i

                                                      • S^x : spin operator in x direction, S^x=12ℏσx=12ℏ[0110]

                                                      • S^z : spin operator in z direction, S^z=12ℏσz=12ℏ[100−1]

                                                      Heisenberg model

                                                      H^=∑<ij>JijS→i^⋅S→j^=∑<ij>Jij(S^ixS^jx+S^iyS^jy+S^izS^zj)=∑<ij>Jij[12(S^i+S^j−+S^i−S^j+)+S^izS^jz]

                                                      Notation

                                                      • S^± : raising/lowering operator , S^±=ℏσ±=ℏ(σx±iσy)

                                                        • S^+S^+|↓⟩=S^+|↑⟩=|null⟩|↑⟩=[10]|↓⟩=[01]|null⟩=[00]

                                                        • (σ±)2=0 : a spin can be flipped only only once

                                                      • M^z : total magnetization , M^z=∑iS^iz

                                                      • conserve total magentization

                                                      • Hamitonian has SU(2) symmetry

                                                      Example : two particles ({|↑↑⟩,|↑↓⟩,|↓↑⟩,|↓↓⟩})

                                                      H^=[14Jij0000−14Jij12Jij0012Jij−14Jij000014Jij]

                                                      XXZ model

                                                      H^=∑<ij>Jij(S^ixS^jx+S^iyS^jy+ΔS^izS^jz)

                                                      • conserve total magentization M^z

                                                      Notation

                                                      • Δ : hyperparameter

                                                      Jordan-Wigner Transformation

                                                      mapping spin models to spinless fermions, derive from XXZ model

                                                      H^=12∑<ij>Jij(c^i†c^j+c^j†c^i+2Δn^in^j)

                                                      Notation

                                                      • c^i/c^i† : Jordan-Wigner transformation operator, c^i=∏j<i(σjz)σi+c^i†=∏j<i(σjz)σi−

                                                        • {c^i,c^j†}=δij

                                                        • {c^i,c^j}={c^i†,c^j†}=0

                                                      • n^i : number operator, n^i=c^i†c^i

                                                      Brute-force method

                                                      [ED] Exact Diagonalization

                                                      diagonalizing the Hamiltonian matrix

                                                      • full spectrum N≈20

                                                      • Lanczos algorithm N≈40

                                                      Lanczos algorithm

                                                      • storage complexity O(2N) compared to dense matrix eigen solvers of O(2N)2

                                                      • ghost state : low-lying eigen values result from round of error that r→n is not fully orthogonal

                                                      Algorithm

                                                      1. find the orthogonalized basis r→i using Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization

                                                        r→0=v→‖v→‖βmr→m=Hr→m−1−αm−1r→m−1−βm−1r→m−2αn=r→n†Hr→nβn=|r→n†Hr→n−1|

                                                      2. express Hamiltonian in tridiagonal matrix

                                                        HM=[α0β1⋯00β1α1⋯00⋮⋮⋱⋮⋮00⋯αM−1βM00⋯βMαM]

                                                      3. eigendecomposite the HM

                                                      4. transform the eigenvectors to the original basis

                                                        • for memory constraint, only store the last three r→n and recompute r→n iteratively to perform basis transformation

                                                      Spin-12 hamitonians

                                                      two possible state |↑⟩ and |↓⟩ bitwise operation (xor) rather than vector

                                                      • S^izS^i+1z : s = s ^ (s>>1)

                                                      • S^i+S^i+1− : s = s ^ (3<<i)

                                                      Example

                                                      assume state s=0112

                                                      then for heisenberg model s~=0112⊕0102=0102 where ⊕ is bitwise xor here.

                                                      Notation

                                                      • S^± : S^±=ℏσ±=ℏ(σx±iσy)

                                                      symmetries

                                                      block diagonalize the Hamitonian and solve within the symmetries' eigenspaces.

                                                      Example : Transverse Field Ising Model

                                                      1. parity operator : P^=⨂iσix, the eigen values are ±1

                                                      2. |ψ⟩=P^M|ψ⟩ : for random state ψ, apply operator for M times we find the initial state again

                                                      3. eigen state becomes : ∑i=0MP^i|ψ⟩

                                                      4. construct hamiltonian from eigen state and eigen vector

                                                      Time evolution

                                                      Trotter-Suzuki decomposition : H^=∑k=1Kh^k→e−iH^Δt/ℏ=∏k=1Ke−ih^kΔt/ℏ+O(Δt2)

                                                      • time-indepedent assumption : |ψ(t+Δt)⟩=e−iH^Δt/ℏ|ψ(t)⟩

                                                      • non-commuting decomposition : H^=∑k=1Kh^k[h^i,h^j]≠0i≠j

                                                      • second order version : e−iH^Δt/ℏ=(∏k=1Ke−ih^kΔt/2ℏ)(∏k=K1e−ih^kΔt/2ℏ)+O(Δt3)

                                                      Example : K=2

                                                      |ψ(t+Δt)⟩=e−ih^1Δt/2ℏe−ih^2Δt/ℏe−ih^1Δt/2ℏ|ψ⟩

                                                      Example : Transverse Field Ising Model

                                                      H^=∑<ij>Jijσizσjz⏟h^1−∑ihiσix⏟h^2

                                                      e−ih^1Δt/ℏ=⨂<ij>e−iΔtJijsizsj6z/ℏ

                                                      e−ih^2Δt/ℏ=[cos(Δthi/ℏ)isin(Δthi/ℏ)isin(Δthi/ℏ)cos(Δthi/ℏ)]

                                                      (since eA=1+A+A22!+⋯ )

                                                      Notation

                                                      • [⋅,⋅] : commute operator, [A,B]=AB−BA=0→A,B commute

                                                      • <i,j> : means i,j are neighbors

                                                      • Jij : connection between site i and j

                                                      • hi : magenatic field at site i

                                                      • h^k : non-commuting term

                                                      • si : eigen value for σiz

                                                      Imaginary-time evlotion: it→τ

                                                      • time-indepedent assumption : |ψ(t)⟩=e−iH^t/ℏ|ψ(0)⟩→|ψ(t)⟩=e−τH^|ψ(0)⟩

                                                      • converges to the ground state by suppressing the amplitudes of excited states exponentially fast in the product ΔEkτ .

                                                      Magnus expansian : U^(Δt)=e−iH¯tΔt/ℏ+O(Δt2)Ht=H¯t1+H¯t2+⋯

                                                      • time-depdent assumption : |ψ(t′)⟩=U(t′,t)|ψ(t)⟩

                                                      • H¯t1=1Δt∫tt+ΔtH^(s)ds and Ht2=−iΔt∫tt+Δtds∫tsdl[H^(s),H^(l)]

                                                      Notation

                                                      • U : evolution operator, U^(t′,t)=e−i∫tt′H^(s)ds/ℏt′>t

                                                      Matrix Product States

                                                      Bipartite entanglement

                                                      Reduced density matrix : ρA=TrB(|ψ⟩⟨ψ|)|ψ⟩∈H=HA⊗HB

                                                      Notation

                                                      • ⊗ : kronecker product, e.g. [1001]⊗[1111]=[1100110000110011]

                                                      • TrB : partial trace over subsystem B , e.g. TrB[A11B11A11B12A12B11A12B12A11B21A11B22A12B21A12B22A21B11A21B12A22B11A22B12A21B21A21B22A22B21A22B22]=[∑iiBiiA11∑iiBiiA12∑iiBiiA21∑iiBiiA22]

                                                      Entanglement : S=−Tr(ρA log ρA)=−Tr(ρB log ρB)

                                                      using Schmidt decomposition ρA=∑αλα2|ϕα⟩A⟨ϕα|A→S−∑αλα2logλα2

                                                      • product state (zero entanglement) : S=0⇔λ1=1,λα>1=0

                                                      • maximally entangled state : S=N2logd⇔λi=1/dN/2

                                                      • random state : S≈N2logd−12

                                                      Area law of entanglement : entanglement entropy scales as S∝LD−1

                                                      Example : 1-D entanglement

                                                      S∼const

                                                      Notation

                                                      • S : entanglement entropy

                                                      • d : Hilbert space dimension

                                                      • λ : eigen value

                                                      • N : number of sites

                                                      • D : dimension of the entanglement system

                                                      • L : linear dimension of system

                                                       

                                                      Matrix Product state

                                                      [MPS] Matrix Product State : |ψ⟩=∑sTr(A1s1⋯ANsN)|s1⋯sN⟩

                                                      • canonical form (normalization) : A=ΛΓ

                                                      Example : GHZ or 'cat' state

                                                      |GHZ⟩=12(|↓⟩⊗N+|↑⟩⊗N)=1Z(Tr((A↑)N)|↑⟩⊗N+Tr((A↓)N)|↓⟩⊗N)

                                                      where Z is a norm and

                                                      Example : AKLT state

                                                      ground state of spin-1 Hamiltonian : H^=∑jS→j^⋅S→^j+1+13(S→^j⋅S→^j+1)2

                                                      with matrices : Ai+=A+=23σ+=[02300]Ai0=A0=−13σz=[−130013]Ai−=A−=−23σ−[00−230]

                                                      the corresponding |+⟩, |−⟩ , |0⟩ are three states for spin-1 particle not for spin-12 particle

                                                      Notation

                                                      • Ai : a rank-3 tensor, Ai∈CD×2×2, D is the number of basis state for single site.

                                                        Aisi means when the site i is in state si, there is a 2×2 matrix for product

                                                        For translationally symmetric Ai=A

                                                      • σ+ : creation / raising operator , σ+=[0010]

                                                        • σ+|↓⟩=0

                                                        • σ+|↑⟩=|↓⟩

                                                      • σ− : annihilation / lowering operator, σ−=[0100]

                                                        • σ−|↓⟩=|↑⟩

                                                        • σ−|↑⟩=0

                                                      • |+⟩ : for spin-1 , |+⟩=|↑↑⟩

                                                      • |−⟩ : for spin-1 , |−⟩=|↓↓⟩

                                                      • |0⟩ : for spin-1 , |0⟩=12(|↑↓⟩+|↓↑⟩)

                                                       

                                                      [MPO] Matrix Product Operator : O^=∑σi,σi′[W1σ1σ1′⋯WNσNσN′]|σ1…σN⟩⟨σ1′⋯σN′|

                                                      • computing ⟨ψ|O^|ψ⟩ :

                                                      Example : single site operator

                                                      O^j=I⊗⋯⊗O^⏟site j⊗⋯⊗I

                                                      Wiσi,σi′=⟨σi|O^|σi′⟩

                                                      Example : paramagnetic system H^=−∑ihS^iz

                                                      H^=(−hS^z⊗I⊗⋯⊗I)+⋯+(I⊗⋯⊗I⊗−hS^z)

                                                      W1=[−hSzI]Wi=[I0−hSzI]WN=[I−hSz]

                                                      Example : Transverse field Ising model H^=−∑iS^izS^i+1z+h∑iS^ix

                                                      W1=[hSx−SzI]Wi=[I00Sz00hSx−SzI]WN=[ISzhSx]

                                                      Notation

                                                      • Wi a rank-4 tensor, Wi∈CD×D×2×2

                                                        Wiσiσj means for site i when the left state is σi and right state σj there is a 2×2 matrix for product

                                                       

                                                      [DMRG] Density matrix renormalization group

                                                      find the ground state that argmin|ψ⟩⟨ψ|H^|ψ⟩⟨ψ|ψ⟩

                                                      • left normalization : A†A=IA′=UΣV†→A=U

                                                      • right normalization : BB†=IB′=UΣV†→B=V†

                                                      • substitution algorithm : imaginary time evolution, but converge slower

                                                      Algorithm

                                                      1. random initialize |ψ⟩ as right-normalized

                                                      2. build R1

                                                      3. repeat until energy converge Var(H)<ϵ

                                                        1. right sweep for l=1,…,L−1

                                                          1. solve eigen value for Ml

                                                          2. left normalize Ml

                                                          3. build Ll

                                                        2. Left sweep for l=L,…,2

                                                          1. solve eigen value for Ml

                                                          2. right normalize Ml

                                                          3. build Rl

                                                       

                                                      [TEBD] Time evolving block decimation

                                                      Algorithm

                                                      1. two site tensor contraction

                                                      2. apply evolution gate

                                                      3. split into single site tensor

                                                      4. truncation : keep χmax eigen value and renormalize ∑iΛii2=1

                                                      Computation errors :

                                                      • truncation error : main error, grows exponentially

                                                      • Trotter error : can be avoid reducing Δt and higher expansion

                                                      • small eigen value : at step 3 Λ−1A and BΛ−1

                                                      • imaginary time evolution : canonical form only retrained when Δτ→0

                                                      Further topics

                                                      Two-dimensional system

                                                      • converting two dimension system as chain

                                                      • [PEPS] projected entangled pair state

                                                        • challenging computationally

                                                        • lack a canonical form

                                                      Mixed state and open quantum system dynamics

                                                      • mixed state unitary time evolution is governed by H^ : ∂tρ^(t)=−i[H^,ρ^(t)]

                                                      • open quantum system : coupled to an environment or bath

                                                        which can be described by Lindblad equation : ∂tρ^=L^ρ^=−i[H^,ρ^]+∑iγi(L^iρ^L^i†−12{L^i†L^i,ρ^})

                                                        Notation

                                                        • L^i : jump operator, the system operators directly coupled to the bath, e.g. creation, annilation

                                                        • L^ : Lindbladian, could be considered as a linear operator |ρ(t)⟩=e−iL^t|ρ0⟩

                                                      schmidt eigenstates belong to a fixed magnetization sector

                                                      [TDVP]Time-dependent variational principle

                                                      • action function : S=∫t1t2⟨ψ(t)|i∂t−H^|ψ(t)⟩dt→∂tAi=−iHiAi

                                                      • analogue to DMRG algorithm, but better at simulate long-ranged

                                                      Quantum Monte Carlo

                                                      Monte Carlo Basics

                                                      Monte Carlo

                                                      • error 1N

                                                      Markov Chain : PXY=T(X→Y)A(X→Y)A(X→Y)=min{1,W(Y)W(X)}

                                                      • Ergodicity : T(X→Y)>0∀X,Y

                                                      • Normalization : ∑YT(X→Y)=1

                                                      • Reversibility : T(X→Y)=T(Y→X), if T not satisfy this, then

                                                      Notation

                                                      • T : transition probability

                                                      • W : static distribution

                                                      • A : accept probability

                                                      Classical Ising model

                                                      symmetry-braking phase transition at a finite temperature

                                                      H=−∑<i,j>Jijσiσj−∑ihσiσi=±1

                                                      Notation

                                                      • Jij : coupling constant

                                                        • Jij≥0 : symmetry-broken state

                                                      • hi : external field

                                                      • <i,j> : means i,j are connected

                                                      • c : cluster, |c| means the number of spins inside a cluster

                                                      • β : inverse temperature, β=1κBT

                                                      • m : magnetization

                                                       

                                                      Algorithm : Swendsen-Wang

                                                      1. two neighboring parallel spins connected with probability p=1−e−2βJ

                                                      2. cluster labeling. e.g., Hoshen-Kopelman algorithm

                                                      3. measurement : ⟨m2⟩C′=1N2∑c|c|2

                                                      4. cluster flipped with probability 12

                                                      Algorithm : Wolff

                                                      1. random site

                                                      2. recursive find parallel neighbor add it to the cluster with p=1−e−2βJ

                                                      3. measurement : ⟨m2⟩C′=1N|c0|, since only one cluster

                                                      4. flip all spins in the clster

                                                      • Swendsen-Wang will result in many small clusters in high dimension, but Wolff will result in one large cluster

                                                      Quantum spin system thermodynamics

                                                      ⟨m^⟩=1ZTr(m^e−βH^)=1Z∑Cm(C)W(C)Z=Tr(e−βH^)=∑CW(C)

                                                      Notation

                                                      • m^ : magnetization

                                                      • β : reverse of temperature β=1κBT

                                                      • Z : partition sum

                                                      • m(C) : magnetization of a configuration C

                                                      • W(C) : weight of a configuration C

                                                      spin-12 in a magnetic field : H^=−hS^z−ΓS^x=[−h2−Γ2−Γ2h2]

                                                      Notation

                                                      • h : longitudinal field

                                                      • Γ : transverse field

                                                      Discrete-time path integral : β=ΔτM

                                                      expand to first order e−ΔτH^=U^+O(Δτ2)→Z≈Tr(U^M)

                                                      Notation

                                                      • U^ : transfer matrix : U^=I−ΔτH^=[1+Δτh2ΔτΓ2ΔτΓ21−Δτh2]

                                                      • Δτ : discrete time step

                                                      • M : resolution

                                                      • E0 : ground energy

                                                      Example : 1D classical Ising model (0D transverse field Ising model)

                                                      H=−J∑iMσiσi+1−h∑iσi with periodic boundary condition σM+1=σ1

                                                      • βJ=−12log(ΔτΓ/2) : off diagonal

                                                      • βh=log(1+Δτh/2) : diagonal

                                                      • βE0=MβJ

                                                      Continous-time path integral : Δτ→0 ???

                                                      d -dimensional quantum spin model ⇔ d+1- dimensional classical Ising model

                                                      Example : 1D classical Ising model (0D transverse field Ising model)

                                                       

                                                      quantum XY model : H^=−∑<i,j>Jxy2(S^i+S^j−+S^i−S^j+)

                                                      spin flip-flops (blue line) proportional to β which is a constant not grow bigger as Δτ→0

                                                      negative sign problem : positive off diagonal lead to negative probabilities

                                                      • solution : ⟨A^⟩W=∑CA(C)W(C)∑CW(C)=∑CA(C)sign(W)|W(C)|/∑C|W(C)|∑Csign(W)|W(C)|/∑C|W(C)|

                                                      • error : β↑,L↑→ϵ↑ error ϵ increase with inverse temperature β and system size L

                                                       

                                                      Variational Monte Carlo

                                                      variational principle : |ψ(θ)⟩=∑nψn(θ)|n⟩

                                                      energy expectation(MCMC) : Eθ=∑n|ψn(θ)|2E1(n)∑n|ψn(θ)|2

                                                      Notation

                                                      • E1(n) : local energy E1(n)=∑m⟨n|H^|m⟩ψm(θ)ψn(θ)

                                                      • Gkl : metric tensor Gkl=⟨O^k∗O^l⟩θ−⟨O^k∗⟩θ⟨O^l⟩θ

                                                      • O : logarithm wave-function derivative O=∇θψn(θ)/ψn(θ)

                                                        • O^=∑nO(n)|n⟩⟨n|

                                                      [SGD]Stochastic Graident Descent : θ←θ−λ∇θEθ

                                                      • ∇θ⟨E⟩θ=2Re{∑nW(n)[E1(n)−Eθ]O(n)}

                                                      Stochastic Reconfiguration : θ←θ−ΔτG−1∇θEθ

                                                      • to avoid small value inverse : G′=β2I+G†Gβ∈R

                                                      Jastrow States : ψn(θ)=exp(∑iaiσi+∑<ij>Jijσiσj)θ={a,J}

                                                      wave function form for spin system

                                                      [NQS]Neural Quantum States : ψn(θ)=MLP({σ1,⋯,σN})

                                                      [MFPWF]Mean-field projected wave function : |ψ(θ)⟩=PG[∑i,j∑s,s′Fijss′c^i,s†c^j,s′†]N/2|0⟩θ=Fijss′∈R2N×2N

                                                      • ψn(θ)=(N/2)!Pf(X)

                                                      represent spin as pesudo-fermions : S^i{x,y,z}=12∑ss′c^i,sσss′αc^i,s′

                                                      Notation

                                                      • PG : Gutzwilller projection operator

                                                      • c^i,s,c^i,s† : fermionic annihlation/creation operator

                                                      • s,s′ : spin of the site, ↑ or ↓

                                                      • i,j : index of the site

                                                       

                                                      Path integrals in quantum statistical mechanics

                                                      ρfree(R→,R→′,Δτ)=⟨R→|e−ΔτT^|R→′⟩=(2πℏ2Δτm)−Nd/2exp(−|R→−R→′|22ℏ2Δτ/m)

                                                      Z=∫dR→ρ(R→,R→)=∫(∏j=1MdR→j)∏j=1M[(2πℏ2Δτm)−Nd/2exp(−R→j−R→j+12ℏ2Δτ/m−ΔτV(R→j))]

                                                      Notation

                                                      • ρfree : density matrix of free particles

                                                      • Z : partition function

                                                      • R→j : (r→1,r→2,⋯,r→N) , N particles position at time j

                                                      • T^,V^ : kinetic, potential terms of Hamiltonian H^, T^=−ℏ22m∂x2

                                                      path sampling method : A(X→X′)=min{1,exp(−m[(r→j−1i−r→ji′)2+(r→ji′−r→j+1i)2]/2ℏ2Δτ)exp(−m[(r→j−1i−r→ji)2+(r→ji−r→j+1i)2]/2ℏ2Δτ)⋅exp(−Δτ[V(R→j′)−V(R→j)])}

                                                      The accept probability of Metropolis algorithm is defined above

                                                      H=∑j∑im2(ℏΔτ)2(r→ji−r→j+1i)2+∑jV(R→j)

                                                      Notation

                                                      • r→ji : position of particle i at time j

                                                      • r→ji′ : displaced position of particle i at time j

                                                      • R→j : (r→1,r→2,⋯,r→N) , N particles position at time j

                                                      • V : potential energy, in most cases it's sum of single-particle and two-particle terms : V^=∑iNvext(r→^i)+∑i<jv(r→^i−r→^j)

                                                      Boson symmetry :

                                                      ρBose=1N!∑Pρ(R→1,PR→2,β)

                                                      [DMC] Diffusion Monte Carlo

                                                      Algorithm

                                                      1. w0α←1,R→0α←R→0

                                                      2. update loop

                                                        1. R→kα∼N(R→k−1α,Δτm) : diffusion update

                                                        2. wkα←wk−1αe−Δτ2[V(R→kα)+V(R→k−1α)]

                                                        3. clone ⌊wkαEα[wkα]+r⌋ times for walker α

                                                      • maximum clones ⇔ Δτ too large

                                                      • scale wα→exp(EtΔτ)wα where Et is trial energy , when Et=E0 stability will achieve.

                                                      Importance sampling : R→k−1←R→k−1+ℏ2Δτ2m2∇ϕt(R→k−1)ϕ(R→k−1)

                                                      before update, add a dift : R→k−1←R→k−1+ℏ2Δτ2m2∇ϕt(R→k−1)ϕ(R→k−1)

                                                      Notation

                                                      • ϕt : trial wavefunction ϕt(R→)=∏i<jfz(|r→i−r→j|)

                                                      • fz : Jastrow factor, two particle coorelations

                                                      Fermionic systems : ϕt′(R→)=ϕt(R→)detl,n[eik→l⋅r→n]

                                                      ϕ0 could be negative, when ϕ→−ϕ should be applied

                                                      Notation

                                                      • : particle index

                                                      • k→l : wave vectors compatible with periodic boundary conditions

                                                      Electronic-structure problem

                                                      Full Hamiltonian of matter

                                                      H^=−∑jNeℏ22m∇r→j2⏟T^e−∑lNnℏ22Ml∇R→l2⏟T^n+12∑i≠jNee2|r→i−r→j|⏟Vee+12∑l≠mNnZlZme2|R→l−R→m|⏟Vnn−∑j=1Ne∑l=1NnZle2|r→j−R→l|⏟Ven+VSO

                                                      Adiabatic (Born-Oppenheimer) approximation : Ml≫m|R→l−R→m|≪|r→i−r→j|

                                                      H^=∑j=1Neℏ22m∇r→j2⏟T^e−∑j=1Ne∑j=1NnZle2|r→j−R→l|⏟Ven+12∑i≠jNee2|r→i−r→j|⏟Vee

                                                      Non-interacing (mean-field) approximation : H^sp=−ℏ22m∇r→2+Veff(r→)

                                                      non-interacting electrons assumption, Ven+VM+Vee→Veff

                                                      Hatree-Fock approximation :

                                                      use a Slater determinant for non-interacting system

                                                      ⟨Φ|H^|Φ⟩=∑i,σ∫d3r→ ϕiσ∗(r→)[−ℏ22m∇2+Ven(r→)]σiσ(r→)+VM⏟T^e+Ven+∑i,j,σ,σ′e2∫d3r→ d3r→′ ϕiσ∗(r→) ϕjσ′∗(r→′)1|r→−r→′|ϕiσ(r→)ϕjσ′(r→′)Hatree interaction−∑i,j,σe2∫d3r→ d3r→′ ϕiσ∗(r→) ϕjσ∗(r→)1|r→−r→′|ϕjσ(r→)ϕiσ(r→′)exchange interaction}VeeTheintegrationshowsthatthewavefunction$ψ$isdefinedinthewholespace

                                                      Notation

                                                      • i,j : index of the single particle state

                                                      • σ,σ′ : spin of the electron, ↑ or ↓

                                                      • ϕiσ(r→) : dnotes for particle i of state σ , the wave function value at position r→

                                                      Configuration-Interaction : |Φ0⟩=(1+∑i,μαμic^i†c^μ+∑i<j,μ<ναμ,νijc^i†c^j†c^μc^ν)|ΦHF⟩

                                                      add interations between electrons correctly and allow calculation of excited state

                                                      Notation

                                                      • |ΦHF⟩ : Hartree-Fock ground state, which is from the Hartree-Fock approximation, |ΦHF⟩=∏μ=1Nc^μ†|nulll⟩

                                                      • c^†,c^ : creation / annihilation operator

                                                      [DFT] Density functional theory

                                                      Hohenberg-Kohn Theorem : for electron system H^=−ℏ22m∑j∇j2⏟T^e+12∑i≠je2|r→i−r→j|⏟V^ee+∫vext(r→)n(r→)dr→⏟V^ext

                                                      • Uniqueness :

                                                      • Variational : n0=argminn E=argminn⟨Ψ|H^|Ψ⟩

                                                      Notation

                                                      • vext(r→) : external potential density

                                                      • n0(r→) : ground state electron density

                                                      • n(r→) : electron density ∑j|ϕj(r→)|2

                                                      Kohn-Sham solution :

                                                      find a non-interacting system that has the same particle density as the interacting one

                                                      Algorithm

                                                      1. initial guess Veff0

                                                      2. solve ϕj (eigen vector) from KS1 : [−ℏ22me∇2+Veff(r→)]ϕj(r→)=εjϕj(r→)

                                                      3. n(r→)←∑i|ϕj(r→)|2

                                                      4. revise Veff from KS 2 : Veff(r→)=∫d3r′n(r→′)|r→−r→′|+μXC(r→)+νext(r→)

                                                      5. goto 2 if |Veffnew−Veffodd|≥threshold

                                                      Notation

                                                      • μXC : functional derivative of the exchange-correlation energy, μXC=dEXCdn

                                                      • EXC : exchange-correlation energy, EXC=⟨Φ|T^|Φ⟩−Ek+⟨Φ|V^ee|Φ⟩−Ec with approximation (local density approximation) EXC≈∫n(r→)εXC(n(r→))dr→=∫n(r→)[εX(n(r→))+εC(n(r→))]dr→

                                                        • uniform electron gas : ε(n(r→))=−34(3π)1/3n(r→)1/3

                                                        • Monte carlo -> interpolation

                                                      • EC : Hartree energy EC=12∫e2n(r→)n(r→′)|r→−r→′|dr→dr→′

                                                      • EK : kinetic energy EK=−ℏ22m∑j⟨ϕj|∇2|ϕj⟩

                                                      Representing the Hilbert space

                                                      Spin-12 system : directly mapped to a qubit

                                                      Fermionic system

                                                      • Jordan-Wigner Transformation : |Ψ⟩=|nN−1,⋯,n0⟩↔|zN−1,⋯,z0⟩ni=zi

                                                        c^i↔AiZi−1⋯Z0c^i†↔Ai†Zi−1⋯Z0Ai=(Xi+iYi)2

                                                        • measuring parity requires O(N) operators

                                                        • updating an occupation number requires O(1) operators

                                                      • Parity Encoding : |Ψ⟩=|nN−1,⋯,n0⟩↔|zN−1,⋯,z0⟩zi=[∑j=0ini]mod 2

                                                        c^i↔XN−1⋯Xi+1(XiZi−1+iYi)c^i†↔XN−1⋯Xi+1(XiZi−1−iYi)

                                                        • measuring parity requires O(1) operators

                                                        • updating an occupation requires O(N) operators

                                                      • Bravyi-Kitaev : a hypbrid of Parity and Jordan-Wigner

                                                      Notation

                                                      • ni : fermionic orbitals/site occupation number ni∈{0,1}

                                                      • c^i,c^i† : creation operator, annihilation operator

                                                      Variational quantum solver

                                                      extract the spectrum of an operator

                                                      [QFT] Quantum fourier transform

                                                      • exact solution

                                                      • vast number of gate operations

                                                      [VQE] Variational Quantum Eigensolver : minθ⟨Ψ(θ)|H^|Ψ(θ)⟩⟨Ψ(θ)|Ψ(θ)⟩

                                                      • quantum computer : expectation evaluation

                                                      • classical computer : optimization COBYLA (no SGD since no gradient)

                                                      [UCC] Unitary Coupled Cluster : |Ψ(θ)⟩=eT^(θ)−T^†(θ)|Ψ0⟩

                                                      • a good choice for variational state

                                                      • huge circuit depth

                                                      • much depend on the choice of state |Φ0⟩

                                                      [UCCSD] Unitary Coupled Cluster with Single and Double excitation

                                                      • T^(θ)≈T^1(θ1)+T^2(θ2)

                                                        • T^1(θ1)=∑i,jθ1,i,jc^i†c^j

                                                        • T^2(θ2)=∑i,jθ2,i,j,k,lc^i†c^k†c^jc^l

                                                      Notation

                                                      • T^(θ) : excitation operator

                                                      • |Ψ0⟩ : Hartree-Fock/single Slater detereminant state
